awd_titl_txt: Alternative Pathways of Stellar Evolution in Open Clusters
awd_abstract_narration:
Our understanding of the life cycle of individual stars is one of the great intellectual accomplishments of the past century. However, half of stars like our Sun form in orbit with companion stars. Going no further than understanding individual stars would be like studying human lives without including people who are in couples. The goal of this research is to understand these alternative stellar life stories, by following stars that are born, live and die in clusters of thousands of stars. The alternative life paths result when two stars orbit near each other. Their life stories can include exchanging material between them, the two slowly merging into one, or even violent stellar collisions. Combining the studies single stars with new understanding of stars in clusters will yield a complete picture of lives of all stars.

This work also will increase participation of students underrepresented in STEM. The research team will develop after-school programs for students at community centers in Madison WI. These programs build on astronomy video games to excite and nurture interest in STEM. The team also will add game-based learning to astronomy and physics classes at the University of Wisconsin and at Madison College. Finally, the team will provide and mentor research experiences for underrepresented undergraduate and graduate students. 

This research seeks to transform our view of stellar life cycles by including the interactions of stars in clusters. The planned research rests upon NSF-funded WIYN Open Cluster Study research that comprehensively defines alternative stellar evolution products, and the close binary populations from which they form, in 6 rich older (1.6 Gyr < t < 8 Gyr) open clusters. The first objective is to theoretically reproduce alternative stellar evolution pathways within all 6 clusters using two numerical modeling codes, called MESA and TWIN. In particular, blue stragglers with detected white-dwarf companions will permit direct, detailed modeling of mass-transfer evolution from progenitor binaries to current blue-straggler binaries. The second objective is to simulate the rotation distributions of stars in clusters, as a function of effective temperature. The rotation trends of main-sequence single stars do not hold, and the actual rotation distributions of not yet known. The third objective is to model angular momentum changes as a function of mass. They will use models of current spin-down rates of stars to constrain the magnitude of spin-up events in stellar formation events.

por.por_cntn:
As many as a quarter of the evolved solar-like stars in old star clusters do not follow the canonical life paths of single stars. Rather than being anomalies, these stars are following frequently traveled alternative pathways of stellar evolution. Most of these stars on alternative evolutionary pahts are in binary pairs of stars, and their origins likely stem from mass transfer, mergers and collisions within these binaries. The overarching research goal of this project was to define and understand the products of these alternative stellar evolution pathways, using old open star clusters as well-populated, accessible laboratories.

The detailed characterization and modeling of these systems has provided new understanding of binary star evolution. Ongoing discovery and detailed study - both observational and theoretical - of these products of solar-like stars in binaries is a critical step to developing better models of binary evolution broadly, shedding light on the early stages of evolution pathways that may lead to diverse, astrophysically important objects including X-ray binaries, double degenerate binaries, and Type 1a supernovae. Their impact on stellar population analyses in clusters, the Milky Way, and in other galaxies may be substantial.

Intellectual Merit: Over the course of this grant, we have:

- Completed the radial-velocity component of the WIYN Open Cluster Study, providing comprehensive censuses of the short-period (periods less than 10,000 days) binary populations of six rich, nearby open clusters. Crucially, WOCS provides orbital parameters for these binaries, which provide the framework for understanding their evoluationary pathways.

-Discovered a new population of alternative pathway products, the blue lurker stars embedded among seemingly typical (main sequence) solar-like stars. These stars represent the extension to lower stellar masses of the long-known blue stragglers.

- Established the very rapid rotation of recently formed mass-transfer products, and the timescale of their subsequent spin-down. The former confirms and constrains theoretical predictions, while the latter permits age determination (gyrochronology) of these alternative path products.

- Searched for surface abundance variations on alternative evolution products. These abundance variations are signatures of the composition of the material transferred onto these stars from companions, and thereby point to the evolutionary states of the donor stars.

- Successfully modeled two alternative pathway binaries, each comprising a blue straggler and a white dwarf. The mass transfer simulations and the associated stellar evolution were remarkably successful at reproducing our extensive observational characterization of both components in each of these two cases.

Broader Impact: Members of the research team have:

- Mentored grade-school students, undergraduate and graduate students, and post-doctoral fellows from backgrounds under-represented in STEM; mentees have continued in STEM and received awards and career positions.

- Done extensive city, state, national and international dissemination of the research done in this grant and astronomy generally, including, programs for young women, a radio series, presentations in state parks (Universe in the Park), and a Fulbright Scholar term in Chile.

- Participated in professional development in culturally responsive research mentoring, in graduate and post-doctoral scientist participation in the public policy process, and at summer schools in scientific methods and skills.

- Led a national network of 44 universities preparing future faculty in evidence-based teaching methods and skills in inclusive teaching.
